title: 108_hr4706
content: The "Fisheries Management Reform Act of 2004" is cited in this section. Amendments in the Act refer to the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act. The representation of the public interest on regional fishery management councils is addressed. Amendments to the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act involve the appointment of members by the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, replacing references to the Secretary in various subsections. The amendment to the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act involves replacing references to the Secretary with the Administrator in subsections, without affecting current council member appointments. The amendment to the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act involves substituting "Secretary" with "Administrator" in council appointments and adding a provision for state officials to represent the general public's interests in marine fish conservation. The amendment to the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act includes adding representatives of conservation organizations to the nomination process for council appointments. Each list of nominees must include representatives from commercial fishing, recreational fishing, and marine fish conservation sectors who do not rely on fishing for income. The amendment to the Magnuson-Stevens Act includes training requirements for appointed council members on fishery science and stock assessment within 6 months of appointment. The amendment to the Magnuson-Stevens Act mandates training for council members on fishery science, economics, legal requirements, conflict of interest policies, and public engagement in fishery management planning. Members receiving training cannot vote on decisions. The amendment to the Magnuson-Stevens Act requires training for council members on various topics. Members who have not completed training cannot vote on decisions. Additionally, a technical correction is made to Section 302(b)(2)(B) of the Act. SEC. 4. QUALIFICATION OF VOTING COUNCIL MEMBERS; DISCLOSURE OF FINANCIAL INTEREST AND RECUSAL. Qualifications of Voting Council Members are amended to include restrictions on committing certain acts and the reference to the Fisheries Management Reform Act of 2004. Additionally, amendments are made to require disclosure of financial interests and recusal by striking the heading and inserting "Disclosure of Financial Interest and Recusal." The text chunk discusses the prohibition on voting and participation in Council decisions related to financial interests that must be disclosed. It also includes amendments to the Qualifications of Voting Council Members regarding restrictions on certain acts and references to the Fisheries Management Reform Act of 2004. The text chunk discusses amendments to voting restrictions for Council members related to financial interests, including inserting language to clarify affected individuals and the financial impact. Amendments are made to voting restrictions for Council members regarding financial interests, including changing "may not" to "shall" and specifying that the Secretary can determine if a Council decision affects an individual's financial interest and vote. Regulations allowing for such determinations must be promulgated within one year. Amendments are made to voting restrictions for Council members regarding financial interests, including changing "may not" to "shall" and specifying that the Secretary can determine if a Council decision affects an individual's financial interest and vote. Regulations allowing for such determinations must be promulgated within one year. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to Section 307(1)(O) (16 U.S.C. 1857(1)(O)). SEC. 5. REGIONAL SCIENCE AND TECHNICAL TEAMS. Section 302(g) (16 U.S.C. 1852(g)) is amended to establish regional science and technical teams consisting of Federal, State, and academic scientists to provide recommendations on acceptable catch and bycatch limits based on scientific information for section 303(e). The bycatch limits should be consistent with national standards, consider predator-prey relationships and ecological factors, protect essential fish habitats, and endangered species. Public input should be allowed for catch and bycatch limits. The regional science and technical team's recommendations, including catch and bycatch limits and habitat protection measures, must be considered by the Secretary and published in the Federal Register. Recommendations must also undergo peer review by qualified independent scientists. Qualified independent scientists involved in fisheries science or marine ecology must have no financial interest in any fishery. SEC. 6. CONTENTS OF FISHERY MANAGEMENT PLANS. The amendment to Section 303(a)(1) requires provisions for the protection, restoration, and promotion of ecosystems, including the associated ecosystem. Conservation and management measures can be modified by a Council to enhance conservation efforts, particularly for forage fish. The Secretary shall develop conservation and management measures based on recommendations from regional science teams for incorporation into fishery management plans. The Secretary shall develop conservation and management measures for fishery management plans, including catch limits, habitat protections, and species protections under the Endangered Species Act.
